alert.note: Alert for Admiralty Island; Annette Island; Cape Fairweather to Lisianski Strait; City and Borough of Juneau; City and Borough of Sitka; City and Borough of Wrangell; City of Hyder; Eastern Chichagof Island; Glacier Bay; Haines Borough and Klukwan; Ketchikan Gateway Borough; Municipality of Skagway; Petersburg Borough; Prince of Wales Island; Western Kupreanof and Kuiu Island (Alaska) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Special Weather Statement issued January 04 at 10:32PM AKST by NWS Juneau
info.description: ...WIDESPREAD SNOW FOR THE PANHANDLE LATE SUNDAY INTO MONDAY... A weakening front is expected to move into the panhandle beginning late Sunday and into Monday. Due to cold, stable air in place, an overrunning event for the inner channels looks to bring modest snow accumulation. At this time, moisture associated with this front looks to be diminishing as it enters the panhandle; however, there is some indication that a trough aloft will bring enhanced precipitation rates, particularly along the Icy Strait corridor. Overall, with the moisture currently expected, guidance has indicated 90% chance that at least 2 inches of snow over 24 hours will occur in areas from Icy Strait down to Sumner Strait. Around Icy Strait, higher amounts are more likely, with a 40% chance of 6 inches or greater in 24 hours. Therefore, storm totals look to range between 2-6 inches over 24 hours with some locally higher amounts. Ketchikan, Sitka, and areas near sea level on PoW Island may have snow to begin with minor accumulations, but this is expected to transition over to a rain-snow mix quickly as warm air moves in. Check back for updates on this evolving weather system as we continue to evaluate the atmospheric conditions that could lead to winter weather impacts.
